misconceptions.name: Implemented an average acceleration calculator instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute average acceleration from initial and final velocities and time (v0, v1, t) instead of implementing the required task of reading 5 integers and printing the sum of the even ones. As a result, the program structure, inputs, and output are all for a different problem and do not address the specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment is to compute the average acceleration given v0, v1, and t, and that the program should read these three values as doubles and apply the formula (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, determine which of them are even using a condition like n % 2 == 0, accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Only three inputs are read, and they are doubles rather than five integers
The core computation is an acceleration formula (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing even numbers
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No conditional check using modulo (n % 2 == 0) to filter even numbers
Output describes 'average acceleration' rather than 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code or reasoning from a different physics-related exercise about average acceleration and did not align their solution with the specific requirements of this problem about summing even integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the physics-specific logic and re-read the problem statement carefully. Design a new solution that (1) reads 5 integers, (2) uses a loop to process each input, (3) uses a condition like n % 2 == 0 to detect even numbers, and (4) accumulates and prints the sum of those even numbers.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to program structure
Using loops to handle multiple inputs
Conditional logic with modulo for even/odd checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variables, types, formula, and output message) corresponds to a standard average-acceleration exercise and none of the required elements for summing even numbers are present, indicating a clear mismatch with the problem requirements.

evidence.note: This code reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration instead of reading five integers and summing the even ones; there is no loop, no modulo-even check, and the output refers to acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem (calculating average acceleration from v0, v1, and t) instead of the required task (calculating the sum of even numbers from 5 user inputs).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the submitted code fulfills the requirements for Q1, confusing it with another assignment or problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q1 asks for the sum of even numbers among 5 integers read from the user, requiring a loop and conditional logic (modulo operator).
symptoms: Reads 3 double inputs instead of 5 integer inputs
Calculates acceleration using a formula ((v1 - v0) / t)
No loop structure or conditional logic for even numbers is present
Output prints 'The average acceleration is...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read or follow the specific instructions for Q1 (Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully re-read the prompt for Q1: Sum of Even Numbers. Your current submission calculates acceleration. You need to implement the logic for reading 5 integers and accumulating the sum of only the even ones.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code addresses an entirely different physics problem, making it 100% incorrect for the current assignment.

evidence.note: The code reads variables (v0, v1, t) and performs a calculation for acceleration, which is irrelevant to the 'Sum of Even Numbers' prompt.

misconceptions.name: Solving wrong problem entirely
misconceptions.description: The student has submitted code for a completely different problem (calculating acceleration from velocities), not the assigned problem of summing even numbers from 5 integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem about acceleration rather than a programming exercise about filtering and summing even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, checking each one to see if it is even (divisible by 2), and accumulating the sum of only those even numbers.
symptoms: Code reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers
Code calculates acceleration (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing even numbers
Output message is about 'average acceleration' not 'sum of even numbers'
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
No accumulator for summing
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code from a different assignment or problem entirely, suggesting either a copy-paste error, file mix-up, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment carefully. You need to: (1) Read 5 integers, (2) Use a loop to check each one, (3) Test if each number is even using n % 2 == 0, (4) Sum only the even numbers, and (5) Print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is objectively solving a different problem. The assignment explicitly asks for sum of even numbers from 5 integers; the code calculates physics acceleration from 3 double values. This is not a partial implementation or minor deviation—it is a completely different program.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers as required by the assignment

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Code calculates acceleration, not sum of even numbers. No accumulator, no modulo check, no loop.

misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, add only the even numbers to a running sum using a condition `n % 2 == 0`, and then print the sum of those even numbers.
symptoms: Reads three double values instead of five integers
Variable names and prompt refer to v0, v1, and t rather than generic integers
Computes `(v1 - v0) / t` instead of summing selected inputs
No loop, no modulus operator, and no accumulator for the sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused or copied a solution for a physics-style acceleration problem and did not align their implementation with the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and list the exact inputs and required outputs. Double-check that your variable names, input types, and formulas match the description (5 integers, even-number check, summing) rather than another problem you may have seen.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, variable names, and formula correspond to an average acceleration problem and do not match any part of the given task to sum even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: The code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation using v0, v1, and t, with no reading of 5 integers, no loop, and no sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a fundamentally different problem. The assignment asks for a program that reads 5 integers and sums the even numbers. The student instead wrote a physics program that calculates acceleration from three velocity and time values.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to calculate average acceleration using the formula (v1 - v0) / t based on the class name 'Q1Acceleration' and the TODO comments referencing velocity and time units.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q1 requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user and calculating the sum of only the even numbers among those 5 integers. The physics acceleration problem is unrelated to this assignment.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure for processing multiple inputs
No conditional logic for checking even numbers
Output is 'The average acceleration is X' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: Y'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have worked on the wrong assignment problem, possibly confusing this with a different physics homework or misreading the assignment statement entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment Q1 carefully. The task is to read 5 integers and sum only the even ones. Start fresh with: (1) a loop to read 5 integers, (2) a conditional to check if each number is even using n % 2 == 0, and (3) accumulation of the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration) with no overlap with the required problem (sum of even numbers). The class name, variable names, and entire logic contradict the assignment specification.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates acceleration using physics formula (v1-v0)/t, which is unrelated to summing even numbers from 5 integers.
Prompt asks for velocity and time values, not 5 integers as required.
Reads 3 doubles; assignment requires 5 integers from user input.
